pages.sentence: I am at the noodle house. The chef makes noodles. Some noodles are long. Some noodles are short.
pages.mathTip: Look at how long each object is.

pages.question: Which noodle is longer?
pages.mathContext: I see two noodles. One is long. One is short.
pages.mathHint: Look at both noodles. Find the one that goes farther.
pages.successMessage: Yes! You found the longer noodle.

pages.sentence: I see breadsticks too. I put them next to each other. Now I can compare them.
pages.mathTip: Line up objects at one end to compare lengths.

pages.question: Which breadstick is shorter?
pages.mathContext: Two breadsticks are lined up at the left. I can see which is shorter.
pages.mathHint: Look for the one that ends first. That one is shorter.
pages.successMessage: Great! You found the shorter breadstick.

pages.sentence: The train has three cars. Car A is long. Car B is longer. Car C is the longest.
pages.mathTip: You can put objects in order from shortest to longest.

pages.menuStory: The chef asks what I want. I look at the menu. I choose my favorite.

pages.question: Which train car is the longest?
pages.mathContext: I see three train cars. They have different lengths.
pages.mathHint: Look at all three. Find the one that goes the farthest.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The blue car is the longest.

pages.question: Which chopstick is the shortest?
pages.mathContext: Three chopsticks are on the table. I need to find the shortest one.
pages.mathHint: Look for the chopstick that is the smallest. It ends first.
pages.successMessage: Nice work! Chopstick 2 is the shortest.

pages.sentence: I can put noodles in order. First the shortest. Then longer. Last the longest.
pages.mathTip: Start with the smallest. End with the biggest.

pages.question: Put the noodles in order from shortest to longest. Which comes first?
pages.mathContext: I have noodle A, noodle B, and noodle C. I need to order them.
pages.mathHint: Find the shortest noodle. That one comes first.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! Noodle B is shortest, so it comes first.

pages.question: Spoon A is 6 units long. Spoon B is 4 units long. Which spoon is longer?
pages.mathContext: Two spoons have different lengths. I compare them.
pages.mathHint: Longer means bigger. Which number is bigger, 6 or 4?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 6 is more than 4, so Spoon A is longer.

pages.sentence: I am at the cookie shop. I see cookies of the same size. I can use cookies to measure things.
pages.mathTip: To measure, use objects that are all the same size.

pages.question: How many cookies long is the tray?
pages.mathContext: I line up cookies along the tray. I count them to measure.
pages.mathHint: Count the cookies. How many cookies fit?
pages.successMessage: Yes! The tray is 4 cookies long.

pages.sentence: I need to line up the cookies carefully. No gaps between them. No overlaps. Then I count.
pages.mathTip: Put units side by side with no spaces and no overlaps.

pages.question: Which way of measuring is correct?
pages.mathContext: I see three ways to measure. Only one has no gaps and no overlaps.
pages.mathHint: Look for units that touch but do not overlap. No spaces between them.
pages.successMessage: Great! Units should touch with no gaps or overlaps.

pages.sentence: I can use crackers to measure too. The bench is 6 crackers long. I counted 6 crackers.
pages.mathTip: You can measure with any same-size objects.

pages.menuStory: The baker shows me the cookie tray. They all look delicious. I choose one.

pages.question: How many crackers long is the box?
pages.mathContext: A box is measured with crackers. I count the crackers.
pages.mathHint: Count all the crackers from one end to the other.
pages.successMessage: Correct! The box is 5 crackers long.

pages.question: The counter is 7 cookies long. How many cookies did I use?
pages.mathContext: I measured the counter with cookies. It is 7 cookies long.
pages.mathHint: If it is 7 cookies long, I used 7 cookies.
pages.successMessage: Yes! You need 7 cookies to measure 7 cookies long.

pages.sentence: The shelf is 9 napkins wide. I used napkins to measure the shelf width.
pages.mathTip: You can measure length, width, or height with units.

pages.question: Plate A is 3 spoons long. Plate B is 5 spoons long. Which plate is longer?
pages.mathContext: Two plates are measured with spoons. I compare the measurements.
pages.mathHint: Which number is bigger, 3 or 5? That plate is longer.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 5 is more than 3, so Plate B is longer.

pages.question: The baker measures the rolling pin. It is 8 cookies long. How many cookies did she use?
pages.mathContext: The rolling pin is measured using cookies as units.
pages.mathHint: The measurement is 8 cookies. So she used 8 cookies.
pages.successMessage: Yes! If it is 8 cookies long, she used 8 cookies.

previewConcepts.concept: Tell time to the half hour

pages.sentence: I am at the train station. I look at the big clock. The clock tells me what time it is.
pages.mathTip: Clocks have an hour hand and a minute hand.

pages.question: What time is it?
pages.mathContext: The clock shows the hour hand on 2. The minute hand is on 12.
pages.mathHint: When the minute hand points to 12, we say o'clock. Look at the hour hand.
pages.successMessage: Yes! It is 2 o'clock.

pages.sentence: When the minute hand points to 12, we say o'clock. The hour hand shows which hour.
pages.mathTip: Minute hand on 12 means o'clock. Hour hand tells the hour.

pages.question: The train leaves at 7 o'clock. Which clock shows 7 o'clock?
pages.mathContext: I need to find the clock that shows 7 o'clock.
pages.mathHint: Look for the hour hand on 7 and the minute hand on 12.
pages.successMessage: Correct! That clock shows 7 o'clock.

pages.sentence: Sometimes the minute hand points to 6. That means half past the hour. It is 30 minutes past.
pages.mathTip: When the minute hand points to 6, say half past.

pages.prompt: Pick your snack for the train ride!
pages.menuStory: The snack cart arrives. I can pick something to eat on the train.

pages.question: What time is it?
pages.mathContext: The hour hand is between 4 and 5. The minute hand points to 6.
pages.mathHint: The minute hand on 6 means half past. The hour hand shows 4.
pages.successMessage: Yes! It is half past 4.

pages.sentence: Digital clocks show time with numbers. 3 colon 00 means 3 o'clock. 3 colon 30 means half past 3.
pages.mathTip: Numbers after the colon show minutes. 00 is o'clock. 30 is half past.

pages.question: The digital clock shows 6 colon 00. What time is it?
pages.mathContext: I see a digital clock. It says 6 colon 00.
pages.mathHint: The number before the colon is the hour. 00 means o'clock.
pages.successMessage: Great! 6 colon 00 is 6 o'clock.

pages.question: What time does this digital clock show?
pages.mathContext: The digital clock displays 8 colon 30.
pages.mathHint: 30 means half past. The hour is 8.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 8 colon 30 is half past 8.

pages.question: The analog clock shows half past 5. What will the digital clock say?
pages.mathContext: I need to match analog time to digital time.
pages.mathHint: Half past 5 means 5 colon 30.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Half past 5 is 5 colon 30.

pages.question: The train arrives at 9 o'clock. What time does it arrive?
pages.mathContext: The schedule says the train comes at 9 o'clock.
pages.mathHint: 9 o'clock means the hour hand is on 9 and the minute hand is on 12.
pages.successMessage: Correct! The train arrives at 9 o'clock.

pages.sentence: I am doing a snack survey. I ask friends what snack they like best. I write down their answers.
pages.mathTip: Data is information we collect and organize.

pages.question: I collected snack data. Apple, banana, apple, orange. How many chose apple?
pages.mathContext: The list shows: apple, banana, apple, orange. I need to count apples.
pages.mathHint: Count how many times apple appears in the list.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Apple appears 2 times.

pages.sentence: I can sort the data into groups. All the apples go together. All the bananas go together. All the oranges go together.
pages.mathTip: Put things that are the same into groups.

pages.question: I sorted snacks. 3 apples, 2 bananas, 1 orange. How many categories did I make?
pages.mathContext: The snacks are sorted into apple group, banana group, and orange group.
pages.mathHint: Count the different groups. Apple is one group. Banana is another. Orange is another.
pages.successMessage: Correct! There are 3 categories: apple, banana, orange.

pages.sentence: I make a picture graph. Each picture stands for one person. I can see the data easily now.
pages.mathTip: A picture graph shows data with pictures. Each picture is one.

pages.menuStory: I am taking a survey. What is your favorite snack? Your vote will be added to the graph.

pages.question: Look at the graph. How many people chose banana?
pages.mathContext: The picture graph shows banana has 2 banana pictures.
pages.mathHint: Count the banana pictures. Each picture is one person.
pages.successMessage: Yes! There are 2 banana pictures, so 2 people chose banana.

pages.sentence: I can use tally marks too. Each line is one. When I get to 5, I draw a line across.
pages.mathConcept: Using tally marks to organize data
pages.mathTip: Tally marks are a way to keep count. 5 makes a group.

pages.question: The tally marks show 3 lines for apple. How many people chose apple?
pages.mathContext: Tally marks for apple: 3 lines. Each line is one person.
pages.mathHint: Count the tally marks. Each mark is one person.
pages.successMessage: Correct! 3 tally marks means 3 people.

pages.question: I have data: cookie, cracker, cookie, cookie, cracker. What are the categories?
pages.mathContext: The data has cookies and crackers. I need to identify the groups.
pages.mathHint: Look at what types appear. Cookie is one type. Cracker is another type.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The two categories are cookie and cracker.

pages.question: The graph shows 4 votes for rice, 3 votes for noodles, and 2 votes for bread. How many people voted in all?
pages.mathContext: I need to add all the votes together.
pages.mathHint: Add all the groups together. 4 plus 3 plus 2.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 4 plus 3 plus 2 equals 9 people voted.

pages.question: I asked 6 friends. 2 like tea, 3 like juice, 1 likes milk. How should I organize this data?
pages.mathContext: I have drink preferences from 6 friends. I need to organize them.
pages.mathHint: Make groups for each drink type: tea, juice, and milk.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Organize by categories: tea, juice, and milk.

pages.sentence: I am at the food court. I see a graph of favorite foods. The graph shows data. I can answer questions by reading the graph.
pages.mathTip: Look at the graph carefully. Count to find answers.

pages.question: How many people chose sushi?
pages.mathContext: The graph shows sushi has 4 pictures. Each picture is one person.
pages.mathHint: Count the sushi pictures in the graph.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 4 people chose sushi.

pages.sentence: I can compare the data. Sushi has the most. Rice has the least. Ramen is in the middle.
pages.mathTip: Most means the biggest amount. Least means the smallest amount.

pages.question: Which food is most popular?
pages.mathContext: I look at the graph. Most popular means it has the most votes.
pages.mathHint: Find the category with the most pictures. That is most popular.
pages.successMessage: Correct! Sushi has the most, so it is most popular.

pages.question: Which food has the least votes?
pages.mathContext: I need to find which food has the smallest number.
pages.mathHint: Look for the category with the fewest pictures.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Rice has the least with only 2 votes.

pages.menuStory: I am at the food court. So many good choices. I pick what I want to eat.

pages.sentence: I can find the difference. Sushi has 4. Rice has 2. Sushi has 2 more than rice.
pages.mathConcept: Finding how many more in data
pages.mathTip: Subtract to find how many more. The bigger number minus the smaller number.

pages.question: Sushi has 4 votes. Ramen has 3 votes. How many more people chose sushi than ramen?
pages.mathContext: I compare sushi and ramen. I need to find the difference.
pages.mathHint: Subtract. 4 minus 3 equals how many more.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 4 minus 3 equals 1. Sushi has 1 more vote.

pages.question: Rice has 2 votes. Ramen has 3 votes. How many fewer people chose rice than ramen?
pages.mathContext: I compare rice and ramen. Fewer means less.
pages.mathHint: Subtract the smaller from the bigger. 3 minus 2.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 3 minus 2 equals 1. Rice has 1 fewer vote.

pages.sentence: A new graph shows drinks. Tea has 5 votes. Juice has 3 votes. Milk has 4 votes.
pages.mathTip: Each new graph tells a different story. Read it carefully.

pages.question: Look at the drinks graph. Which drink is most popular?
pages.mathContext: Tea has 5, juice has 3, milk has 4. I need to find which is most.
pages.mathHint: Compare all three numbers. Which is biggest? 5, 3, or 4?
pages.successMessage: Correct! Tea has 5 votes, which is the most.

pages.question: How many people voted for drinks in total?
pages.mathContext: Tea has 5, juice has 3, milk has 4. I add them all.
pages.mathHint: Add all three categories. 5 plus 3 plus 4.
pages.successMessage: Excellent! 5 plus 3 plus 4 equals 12 people total.

pages.question: The graph shows 6 people like dumplings and 4 people like spring rolls. How many more people like dumplings?
pages.mathContext: I need to compare dumplings and spring rolls to find the difference.
pages.mathHint: Subtract to find how many more. 6 minus 4.
pages.successMessage: Yes! 6 minus 4 equals 2. Dumplings has 2 more votes.
